headline: CNN This Morning
subHeadline: Today: Johnson Faces Speakership Test With Vote To Avert Shutdown; Impacts Of Climate Change Expected To Worsen Over Next Decade; Trump Campaign Pushes Back On Reports About Plans For Second Term. Aired 7:30-8a ET

utterances.speaker: PHIL MATTINGLY, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: And on U.S. soil, too.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yeah.Donie O'Sullivan, great piece. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: POPPY HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Thank you.It is crunch time on Capitol Hill. Just three days left to avoid a government shutdown. Where things stand ahead of today's critical vote.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: And Wall Street, today, bracing for a critical new gauge of where inflation stands. What the report is expected to reveal and what it will mean for the Fed's rate hikes. Stay with us.(COMMERCIAL)

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: I'm pretty -- I'm pretty sure everybody up there is pretty cognizant that next week is Thanksgiving as well and that might have something to do with the amenable nature of folks. We'll have to see.Lauren Fox, keep us posted. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Phil, you're so cynical. No one wants to go home --

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Yes, I am.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: -- for Thanksgiving. All right, take a look at the economy here. Stock futures pretty flat this morning just ahead of the release of the monthly Consumer Price Index. That's, of course, a key inflation measure.The October report will come out before the opening bell in less than an hour. It's expected to show a headline inflation rate of 3.3 percent. That is down from 3.7 percent in September, according to Bloomberg. Americans did pay less for gas last month but underlying pressures remain very heavy. The Fed has not yet said it will end its historic interest rate increases. Bank of America anticipates a 1.8 percent month-over-month drop in energy prices driven by lower gas. It did fall pretty sharply last month.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Well, over a dozen federal agencies sounding the alarm on the impacts of climate change in America. The dire new details from their report just out this morning.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Despite the bleak outlook, one city known for extreme weather may have some answers on climate change. Our Bill Weir has the latest. Bill, good morning.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Well, new this morning, a stark new report from more than a dozen federal agencies shows that the impacts of global warming are being felt in every corner of the U.S., and things are projected to get worse over the next decade.CNN's Bill Weir joins us now from Niagara Falls. Bill, on this report -- there's never a ton of good news in this space, but what stood out to you in this congressionally mandated report?

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: Well, this is the first time Phil that they've really looked at the economics -- the costs of this phenomenon right now -- and it is knee-buckling when it comes to the expense.We're at $25 billion storms just this year. They're projecting a 25 percent decrease in worker productivity for anybody who works outside in future summers. It is expensive. It is unfair. The people with the smallest carbon footprints are suffering the most. But there is so much hope given the fact that we have all the tools for our survival right here, and they're the most expensive -- or inexpensive options in human history. Onshore wind and solar panels with batteries are the cheapest forms of energy now humanity has ever known. But the sluggish shift away from the fuels that burn -- oil, gas, and coal -- means it's only happening at about one percent a year when it needs to happen at six percent a year to avoid the maximum pain. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE) WEIR (voice-over):  There's an old joke that tells us there are only two seasons in Buffalo -- winter and the Fourth of July. But in the age of global warming the city wants you to know that now their weather is going from punchline to lifeline. Thanks to its Goldilocks location amid the Great Lakes, Buffalo has never reached 100 degrees.

utterances.speaker: STEPHEN VERMETTE, PROFESSOR AND CLIMATE SCIENTIST, BUFFALO STATE UNIVERSITY
utterances.sentences: We get -- you know, on average, about three days in the summer get to be 90 degrees or higher.

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: VERMETTE
utterances.sentences: I mean, if you're in -- if you're in Phoenix, you're looking at that and saying what the heck --

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: VERMETTE
utterances.sentences: -- are you calling that a heat wave?

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: That's mild.WEIR (voice-over):  And when Professor Stephen Vermette did a deep dive of the records the Buffalo state climatologist was shocked to find no increase in droughts or floods.

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: There was this epic snowstorm last winter --

utterances.speaker: VERMETTE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WIER
utterances.sentences: -- really deadly and destructive.

utterances.speaker: VERMETTE
utterances.sentences: Yeah, the blizzard of '22.

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: But that's not an indication that those are going to get worse?

utterances.speaker: VERMETTE
utterances.sentences: No, because we had the blizzard of '77, the blizzard of '85, '81, the blizzard of '36. I'm not saying that our severe weather is going to disappear -- it's still there.

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: VERMETTE
utterances.sentences: In fact, snow amounts have remained steady in all of this. It doesn't seem to be getting worse --

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: Um-hum.

utterances.speaker: VERMETTE
utterances.sentences: -- and that's the key here. We're still going to have severe weather --[07:45:00] WEIR:  Right.

utterances.speaker: VERMETTE
utterances.sentences: -- like the wind and everything else --

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: VERMETTE
utterances.sentences: -- but we're -- it's not going to get worse.

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: I've got to say it's pretty ironic and telling about the world we now live in that a place sort of associated with cold jokes --

utterances.speaker: MAYOR BYRON BROWN, BUFFALO, NEW YORK
utterances.sentences: Right, right.

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: -- and Super Bowl losses could be a huge winner relative on a hotter planet.

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: That's -- you know, that's the way we look at it as well. There was a professor from Harvard that was talking about the effects of climate change and listed some cities that would be considered climate refuges --

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: -- in the future, and Buffalo was one of the cities on the list. And so, we just leaned into it. We are going to not only call ourselves a climate refuge city but do the kinds of things that are required to be welcoming with migration, with new Americans coming here, with seeing the first population growth in the city since the 1950 census.WEIR (voice-over):  After Hurricane Maria, 3,000 Puerto Ricans became permanent Buffalonians -- ANTHONY MATTE, TEACHER'S AIDE:  It was hard because when the hurricanes start -- what do we do? We move from the second floor and we move through the first floor. WEIR (voice-over):  -- including Anthony Matte, who is now a teacher's assistant.

utterances.speaker: MATTE
utterances.sentences: I remember when I moved here people told me oh, you know where you're going because in Puerto Rico it's always warm. It's hot. And I said no. And I moved here like in winter. But I like it -- it's good.

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: Did you consider other spots or what was it about this place that appealed to you the most?

utterances.speaker: HOLLY JEAN BUCK, ASSISTANT PROFESSOR, UNIVERSITY OF BUFFALO
utterances.sentences: The Great Lakes, the freshwater, the projections of climate change looked like Buffalo might have a climate more like New York, Philadelphia toward the end of the century.WEIR (voice-over):  Wildfire smoke helped drive Holly Jean Buck and her family out of Southern California. And as a climate scientist, she says she was welcomed with open arms and employment. BUCK:  But really, it's the energy of the people. People are really forward-thinking in western New York and New York State about what opportunities there might be in clean energy and clean tech, and how to build those solutions in ways that are good for communities.

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: So it's not just the latitude, it's the attitude --

utterances.speaker: BUCK
utterances.sentences: Yeah, exactly.

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: -- right --

utterances.speaker: BUCK
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: -- and the welcoming spirit of the place, I suppose.

utterances.speaker: BUCK
utterances.sentences: The city of good neighbors, they call it.

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: Oh, nice.

utterances.speaker: BUCK
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: Nice, nice. And you found that to be the case?

utterances.speaker: BUCK
utterances.sentences: I have, totally.

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: Yeah?

utterances.speaker: BUCK
utterances.sentences: Yeah.(END VIDEOTAPE) WEIR (on camera):  They're a little depressed in Buffalo after last night's loss to Denver. But in 2019, the mayor of Buffalo declared that city an official climate refuge. And as you saw there, some people are taking them up on that offer there. The population is growing. As the belly of the planet around the equator warms up, the southern latitudes in the United States will become increasingly harder to live in, and so the upper tier is looking like it's more advantageous. Much better to be on a defrost setting than on a broil -- Phil, Poppy.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: No question about it. That is so fascinating. I also hope, Bill, that Wolf Blitzer was not there to hear your criticism of the Buffalo Bills' record thus far this season.Thank you, Bill. Great reporting.

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: You bet. You bet.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: This morning, the civil fraud trial against former President Trump and the Trump Organization resumes in Lower Manhattan. Trump's defense team expected to call a tax attorney for the Trump Org. to the stand today.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Meanwhile a deposition from one of Donald Trump's criminal trials is garnering a lot of attention this morning. ABC News and The Washington Post got video of former Trump lawyer Jenna Ellis talking to Georgia prosecutors in their election interference case. In that video, Ellis describes a conversation she had with top Trump aid, then and now, Dan Scavino, in late 2020.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: JENNA ELLIS, FORMER TRUMP CAMPAIGN ATTORNEY
utterances.sentences: He said to me in a kind of an excited tone well, we don't care and we're not going to leave. And I said what do you mean? And he said well, the boss, meaning President Trump -- and everyone understood the boss -- that's what we all called him. He said the boss is not going to leave under any circumstances. We are just going to stay in power. And I said to him well, it doesn't quite work that way, you realize. And he said we don't care.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Joining us now to discuss is CNN political commentator, Alyssa Farah Griffin. Writer of the "Very Serious" newsletter and podcast host, Josh Barro. And CNN political analyst and New York Times national political reporter Astead Herndon.Alyssa, I want to start with you because can you describe who Dan Scavino is? Like, this isn't some random guy.

utterances.speaker: ALYSSA FARAH GRIFFIN, CNN POLITICAL COMMENTATOR, FORMER TRUMP WHITE HOUSE COMMUNICATIONS DIRECTOR
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: He is literally everywhere always with the president since the campaign of '15.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: Yes. He is one of his right-hand men. He was actually deputy chief of staff in the final stretch of the Trump administration. His office was right outside -- it was in the outer Oval Office because he was the person that Trump would say get me Dan. He'd help him craft tweets. Very, very close and still very much in the inner circle.What stood out to me is I think Jenna Ellis is going to prove to be a very formidable witness on -- in Georgia, which I'm not sure we kind of knew where she would flush out in this. But what she says echoes almost directly what Mark Meadows, the then- White House chief of staff, said to me on December 3. I'd gone into his office and said I'm planning to resign. And he said, with another aide present, what if I told you we weren't going to leave office? And I tendered my resignation the next day. So I've shared that with federal prosecutors and with the congressional committee. But I think you're going to find that at the highest tier of the Trump White House there was a plan to try to stay in power at any cost.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: You know, this, Astead, really tracks Trump's comments about vermin over the weekend.

utterances.speaker: ASTEAD HERNDON, CNN POLITICAL ANALYST, NATIONAL POLITICAL REPORTER, THE NEW YORK TIMES
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: It really tracks the great reporting that's been done by CNN, by The Washington Post --

utterances.speaker: HERNDON
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: -- and by The New York Times about what a second Trump term would look like, according to Trump and those around him. The Trump team is pushing back on that. They're calling that essentially speculative and theoretical. But Phil made the great point just look on the website --

utterances.speaker: HERNDON
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: HERNDON
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: When someone tells you who are, believe them kind of thing?

utterances.speaker: HERNDON
utterances.sentences: Yeah, exactly. I mean, I think the reason why this stuff is kind of landing is because Trump has laid out his own stakes of 20 -- what his next term would look like. And it is the more authoritarian. It is escalated rhetoric. It is using the levers of the federal government to target political opponents.And we know that this was a hallmark of the Trump administration the first time, but I think we are seeing someone who frankly has said that I'm not going to spend those first couple of years maybe playing nice with Washington like I did last time. I'm going to use this as the kind of premise of my administration. When he talked about retribution in that speech, that's really the undergirding theme of what we've seen kind of the Trump campaign lay out in this kind of GOP primary, and I think it's starting to set in for folks. The reason you see the Nikki Haleys or some other people kind of rising is because there is a real recognition that this version of Donald Trump, although it's the same character from last time, does have a kind of clear-eyed rhetoric that I think promises an authoritarian bend to this next version of himself, and I don't think that should be ignored.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: He has a record and he has proposals going forward, plus all the rhetoric, Josh. I'm sorry I'm not going to ask about reciprocal tariffs. I know you and I want to have that discussion very badly.JOSH BARRO, AUTHOR, "VERY SERIOUS" NEWSLETTER ON SUBSTACK:  I'm sure we can.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: But to that point, there is -- the Biden folks always complain we're not focused on policy. You're not covering what we're doing that's having an effect on the economy or on health care, or on drug pricing.There is a comparative --

utterances.speaker: BARRO
utterances.sentences: Um-hum.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: -- in terms of policy that the Trump team has up on their website. He talks about it.Is that something that will break through at some point, or is it going to be just talking about what he says all the time?

utterances.speaker: BARRO
utterances.sentences: Well, I mean, I assume that abortion is eventually going to a more central part of the campaign than it has been right now. I'm sort of surprised that we seem to be setting up for an election that is a referendum election on Joe Biden, which I just find to be a shocking thing when Donald Trump --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: You mean because it's not on Trump?

utterances.speaker: BARRO
utterances.sentences: Right. You know, how can you possibly have something that involves Donald Trump that is not primarily about Donald Trump? Like a theme of our politics for the last eight years has been Donald Trump blocking out the sun. And for whatever reason, this campaign is really about Joe Biden --

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Why, then?

utterances.speaker: BARRO
utterances.sentences: -- and Donald Trump --

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: To that point -- it's a great point.

utterances.speaker: BARRO
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Why?

utterances.speaker: BARRO
utterances.sentences: I -- you know, I think a substantial part of it is that he's not on Twitter. Donald Trump -- whether this is a conscious choice on his part or not -- and I think it is -- is really not trying to drive the news cycle in the way that he did day after day for years.

utterances.speaker: HERNDON
utterances.sentences: I think this is true now, but I think this is kind of turning to the point about people laying out where the reality of the next Trump administration will look like as the primary starts happening and he gets closer to the nomination, and as the legal calendar really puts that attention back on him next year. I think that we can see this.I think right now it is really about Joe Biden and the Democrats won't like that. They would want this to be about the kind of stakes and the alternative.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: And I think the more -- you know, this New York Times reporting was incredible about what they want to do in terms of locking up illegal immigrants and mass deportations which, by the way, the Trump team directed those reporters to Stephen Miller --

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: -- who gave those quotes. Then the campaign realized this is radioactive in a general election. You're going to lose Independents, moderates, and Republicans. They then tried to walk it back. Get ready for that to be a common theme.Susie Wiles knows what she's doing when he puts out there some of his most dangerous rhetoric and ideas. The campaign is going to be like oh, no -- look no further.

utterances.speaker: HERNDON
utterances.sentences: Yeah, yeah.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: But in a second term, he's not constrained by running for reelection.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: And the thing that kept guardrails when he had the craziest ideas is people like myself ran to him and would be like you've got to win an election again. You can't do this. That was like the only way you could communicate something. He will not have that in a second term.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Nikki Haley, who has seen sort of a steady rise -- it's nowhere near where Trump is in the polls -- but her language about Trump has remained pretty subdued, pretty muted in terms of criticism of him. She went there a bit in the debate but not that much.Now, Tim Scott drops out. Many people look at does that help Nikki Haley? Do you think that her language and how she talks about Trump and these policies changes going forward as she tries to be the one who can take him on?

utterances.speaker: BARRO
utterances.sentences: I mean, the difficulty that has faced Haley and all the non- Trump candidates is that the usual set of criticisms you might lodge against Donald Trump are completely unimpressive to the voters in the Republican primary.And so, I think that it's not that they're stupid in that they forgot to attack the frontrunner, it's that it's legitimately very difficult to come up with a strategy for doing that that will actually cause you to pick up votes in this campaign. And, I mean, Tim Scott is -- has dropped out. The Des Moines Register- NBC poll in Iowa found his support splitting in exact thirds --

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: BARRO
utterances.sentences: -- among Ron DeSantis --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: BARRO
utterances.sentences: -- Nikki Haley, and Donald Trump. So I think that the problem of consolidating remains very serious.But the problem is that DeSantis and Haley have a very different pitch for being --

utterances.speaker: HERNDON
utterances.sentences: Yeah.
